comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: I've taken the bait. Called to the bar according to Belfast Newsletter, Saturday, November 11, 1871

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Thomas Richard Wright of Clonakilty was a solicitor in 1854, and his eldest son RIchard was called to the bar in November 1884.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
Deaths column, Freeman's (Dublin) September 3, 1855
May 9th, at Melbourne, Australia, Walter W,. eldest son of the late F. W. Atkin, Esq., of Fern-hill, county Cork.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: From the DIA: Name: HILL, WILLIAM HENRY [1] Building: CO. CORK, CLONAKILTY, FERN HILL Date: 1896 Nature: Adds. & imps. to residence of H.T. Wright. Refs: IB 38, 1 Sep 1896, 185

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Fern Hill on the OS 25" map of 1907, and on the 6" map of 1841.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Here is H.T. Wright in the 1901 census. Occupation: Crown Solicitor He was 51, so born in 1850.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: From Guy's directory of Cork, 1876: Solicitors. Noonan Francis Youghals house Wright Henry T Fern hill Wright Thomas, Fern hill

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Their brother, George Wright, is in Wikipedia! Solicitor General for Ireand, and on the High Court bench until his death in 1913.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: From the Landed Estates database at NUIG: AT the time of Griffith's Valuation, this property was being leased from the Earl of Shannon's estate by Anna Atkins. It was then valued at £28. In 1837, Lewis refers to it as the seat of W.F. Atlkin. Now part of the Fernhill House hotel complex.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Thank you Irish Flickroonies for all the information!  I am not sure quite what to make of it and the reason this photo is in the album, or the connection of the Wrights and Atkins to Edward Hungerford.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/33147718@N05] might know more!  Watch this space ...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Here is an Australian connection - Brisbane Courier 21/11/1868 p.4 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/1312709 -
" DEATH. ATKIN. -- On the 20th November [1868] at her son's residence, Leichhardt-Street, Spring-hill [Brisbane, Queensland], Alice Hungerford [her maiden name?], widow of the late William Francis Atkin, Esq,, of Fern-Hill, in the County of Cork, aged 62. "

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
And another - Brisbane Courier 11/6/1872 p.1 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/1290499
" DEATHS - ATKIN. -- On 25th May [1872] at Sandgate, Robert Travers, youngest and last surviving son of the late William Francis Atkin, Esq., of Fern Hill, county Cork, Ireland, aged 30. "
And a bio of Robert Travers Atkin from The Catholic Press 29/3/1923 (much later) - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/106284311 And much more info about him - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/36886830 , though I fear this might be a bit of a red herring!

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] Thanks for your input, we will have to search around & see if we have any more photos of Ireland! We have added all of this information to our records :)

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] I think we have a winner! From Ancestry.com Edward (Ned) Hungerford, born 10 June 1863 in Cahirmoore, Ireland (COUNTY CORK), died 24 June 1956 in Newtown, Sydney. Son of Henry Jones Hungerford and Mary Boone Cowper. An Edward (Ned) Hungerford of the RSYS (p31 1926). Event of RSYS 1945 with Edward Hungerford, one of the oldest members of the squadron... wearing a yachting cap he acquired in 1877, SMH 22 October. (An Ancestry.com record for Henry Jones Hungerford records his death as at Clonakilty in 1905).
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Here is Henry Jones Hungerford aged 75, in Cahermore in Cork (Ireland!) the 1901 census, with Mary Boone Hungerford, 63. The house they lived in is recorded as 1st class, 23 rooms, so it should be findable on a map... Yes, here it is in Landed Estates, and on the OS 25". It was destroyed in 1921 during the War of Independence. The house would have been at the far side of the field in this Streetview.. You can still see a big stone wall at right, which seperated the fields beyond from the grounds of the house.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
So, what's the story? The Wrights are nothing to do with anything, they just owned the house later.

The Atkin family lived in Fern Hill, the Hungerfords in Cahermore House. Alice Hungerford married William Francis Atkin, and Robert Travers Atkin was born in Fern Hill, 1841. Henry Jones Hungerford was 20 years younger than Alice - her younger  brother?

Alice and William, with young Robert,  William's older brother Walter Atkins and Alice's nephew Ned Hungerford all went to Australia. The Wrights may have bought Fern Hill at this point.

Ned Hungerford left behind a photo album, and in it is a picture of Fern Hill, where his Aunt and his cousin Robert used to live.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] That looks like the story. It is complicated. There was also an Emmanuel Hungerford who emigrated in 1827 with his family (which may be another red herring) - see 4th picture down - . www.askaboutireland.ie/reading-room/history-heritage/big-...
